sentence.text: Drug Label for drug brand INNOPRANXL, containing propranolol hydrochloride.

mmtx.phraseText: Drug Label for drug brand INNOPRANXL,

sentence.text: INNOPRAN XL (propranolol hydrochloride) is a nonselective, beta-adrenergic receptor-blocking agent for oral administration, available as an extended release product.

mmtx.phraseText: a nonselective, beta-adrenergic receptor-blocking agent for oral administration,

sentence.text: These membranes are designed to retard release of propranolol hydrochloride for several hours after ingestion followed by the sustained release of propranolol.

mmtx.phraseText: followed by the sustained release of propranolol.

sentence.text: The active ingredient in INNOPRAN XL is a synthetic beta-adrenergic receptor-blocking agent chemically described as 1-(Isopropylamino)-3-(1-naphthyloxy)-2-propanol hydrochloride.

mmtx.phraseText: The active ingredient in INNOPRAN XL
a synthetic beta-adrenergic receptor-blocking agent chemically
a synthetic beta-adrenergic receptor-blocking agent chemically
The active ingredient in INNOPRAN XL

sentence.text: Each capsule for oral administration contains sugar spheres, ethylcellulose, povidone, hypromellose phthalate, diethyl phthalate, hypromellose, polyethylene glycol, gelatin, titanium dioxide, and black iron oxide.
In addition, INNOPRAN XL 120 mg capsules contain yellow iron oxide.

Propranolol is contraindicated in 1) cardiogenic shock, 2) sinus bradycardia, sick sinus syndrome, and greater than first-degree block unless a permanent pacemaker is in place, 3) bronchial asthma, and 4) in patients with known hypersensitivity to propranolol hydrochloride.

Although beta-blockers should be avoided in overt congestive heart failure, some have been shown to be highly beneficial when used with close follow-up in patients with a history of failure who are well compensated and are receiving additional therapies, including diuretics as needed.
Beta-adrenergic blocking agents do not abolish the inotropic action of digitalis on heart muscle.
Propranolol should be administered with caution in this setting since it may block bronchodilation produced by endogenous and exogenous catecholamine stimulation of beta-receptors.
Propranolol is a competitive inhibitor of beta-receptor agonists, and its effects can be reversed by administration of such agents, e.g., dobutamine or isoproterenol.

mmtx.phraseText: a competitive inhibitor of beta-receptor agonists,
a competitive inhibitor of beta-receptor agonists,

sentence.text: However, such patients may be subject to protracted severe hypotension.

ellipsisSentence.text: Propranolol is a competitive inhibitor of beta-receptor agonists, and its effects can be reversed by administration of such agents, e.g., dobutamine or isoproterenol.
Propranolol is a competitive inhibitor of beta-receptor agonists, and its effects can be reversed by administration of such agents, e.g., dobutamine or isoproterenol.

sentence.text: Beta-adrenergic blockade may prevent the appearance of certain premonitory signs and symptoms (pulse rate and blood pressure changes) of acute hypoglycemia, especially in labile insulin-dependent diabetics.
Propranolol may change thyroid-function tests, increasing T4 and reversing T3, and decreasing T3.

While taking beta-blockers, patients with a history of severe anaphylactic reaction to a variety of allergens may be more reactive to repeated challenge, either accidental, diagnostic, or therapeutic.
In patients with hypertension, use of propranolol has been associated with elevated levels of serum potassium, and serum transaminases and alkaline phosphatase.

mmtx.phraseText: associated with elevated levels of serum potassium,

sentence.text: In severe heart failure, the use of propranolol has been associated with increases in blood urea nitrogen.
Caution should be exercised when INNOPRAN XL is administered with drugs that have an effect on CYP2D6, 1A2, or 2C19 metabolic pathways.

entity.text: drugs that have an effect on CYP2D6 metabolic pathways
drugs that have an effect on 1A2 metabolic pathways
drugs that have an effect on 2C19 metabolic pathways

sentence.text: Co-administration of such drugs with propranolol may lead to clinically relevant drug interactions and changes on its efficacy and/or toxicity (see CLINICAL PHARMACOLOGY, Drug Interactions).

sentence.text: Plasma propranolol levels may increase with acute alcohol consumption and decrease upon chronic alcohol use.
When combined with beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors can cause hypotension, particularly in the setting of acute myocardial infraction.
The antihypertensive effects of clonidine may be antagonized by beta-blockers.
INNOPRAN XL should be administered cautiously to patients withdrawing from clonidine.
Prazosin has been associated with prolongation of first dose hypotension in the presence of beta-blockers.
Postural hypotension has been reported in patients taking both beta-blockers and terazosin or doxazosin.
Propafenone has negative inotropic and beta-blocking properties that can be additive to those of propranolol.

entity.text: negative inotropic properties that can be additive
negative beta-blocking properties that can be additive

sentence.text: Quinidine increases the concentration of propranolol and produces greater degrees of clinical beta-blockade and may cause postural hypotension.

entity.text: produces greater degrees of clinical beta-blockade

sentence.text: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic agent with negative chronotropic properties that may be additive to those seen with -blockers such as propranolol.

mmtx.phraseText: an antiarrhythmic agent with negative chronotropic properties

entity.text: negative chronotropic properties that may be additive

sentence.text: The clearance of lidocaine and bupivacaine are significantly reduced with administration of propranolol.
Lidocaine and bupivacaine toxicity has been reported following coadministration with propranolol.
(see also PRECAUTIONS, Drug Interactions, Non-Cardiovascular Drugs, Anesthetic Agents)
Caution should be exercised when administering INNOPRAN XL with drugs that slow A-V nodal conduction, e.g. digitalis, lidocaine, and calcium channel blockers.

entity.text: drugs that slow A-V nodal conduction

sentence.text: Caution should be exercised when patients receiving a beta-blocker are administered a calcium-channel-blocking drug with negative inotropic and/or chronotropic effects.

entity.text: calcium-channel-blocking drug with negative inotropic and/or chronotropic effects

mmtx.phraseText: a calcium-channel-blocking drug with negative inotropic

sentence.text: Both agents may depress myocardial contractility or atrioventricular conduction.

ellipsisSentence.text: Caution should be exercised when patients receiving a beta-blocker are administered a calcium-channel-blocking drug with negative inotropic and/or chronotropic effects.
Caution should be exercised when patients receiving a beta-blocker are administered a calcium-channel-blocking drug with negative inotropic and/or chronotropic effects.
Caution should be exercised when patients receiving a beta-blocker are administered a calcium-channel-blocking drug with negative inotropic and/or chronotropic effects.
Caution should be exercised when patients receiving a beta-blocker are administered a calcium-channel-blocking drug with negative inotropic and/or chronotropic effects.

sentence.text: There have been reports of significant bradycardia, heart failure, and cardiovascular collapse with concurrent use of verapamil and beta-blockers.

mmtx.phraseText: cardiovascular collapse with concurrent use of verapamil

sentence.text: Co-administration of propranolol and diltiazem in patients with cardiac disease has been associated with bradycardia, hypotension, high degree heart block, and heart failure.
Both digitalis glycosides and beta-blockers slow atrioventricular conduction and decrease heart rate.
Concomitant use can increase the risk of bradycardia.

ellipsisSentence.text: Both digitalis glycosides and beta-blockers slow atrioventricular conduction and decrease heart rate.
Both digitalis glycosides and beta-blockers slow atrioventricular conduction and decrease heart rate.

sentence.text: Patients on long-term therapy with propranolol may experience uncontrolled hypertension if administered epinephrine as a consequence of unopposed alpha-receptor stimulation.

mmtx.phraseText: administered epinephrine as a consequence of unopposed alpha-receptor stimulation.

sentence.text: Epinephrine is therefore not indicated in the treatment of propranolol overdose (see OVERDOSAGE).

mmtx.phraseText: indicated in the treatment of propranolol overdose

sentence.text: Propranolol is a competitive inhibitor of beta-receptor agonists, and its effects can be reversed by administration of such agents, e.g., dobutamine or isoproterenol.

mmtx.phraseText: a competitive inhibitor of beta-receptor agonists,
a competitive inhibitor of beta-receptor agonists,

sentence.text: Also, propranolol may reduce sensitivity to dobutamine stress echocardiography in patients undergoing evaluation for myocardial ischemia.

Patients receiving catecholamine-depleting drugs, such as reserpine and INNOPRAN XL, should be closely observed for excessive reduction of resting sympathetic nervous activity, which may result in hypotension, marked bradycardia, vertigo, syncopal attacks, or orthostatic hypotension.
Methoxyflurane and trichloroethylene may depress myocardial contractility when administered with propranolol.
The clearance of local amide anesthetics (e.g., lidocaine, bupivacaine, mepivacaine) is reduced with administration of propranolol.

mmtx.phraseText: The clearance of local amide anesthetics

sentence.text: Lidocaine and bupivacaine toxicity has been reported following coadministration with propranolol.
Caution should be exercised when amide anesthetic agents are administered concomitantly with propanolol.
The hypotensive effects of MAO inhibitors or tricyclic antidepressants may be exacerbated when administered with beta-blockers by interfering with the beta-blocking activity of propranolol.

mmtx.phraseText: The hypotensive effects of MAO inhibitors
interfering with the beta-blocking activity of propranolol.

sentence.text: Hypotension and cardiac arrest have been reported with the concomitant use of propranolol and haloperidol.

mmtx.phraseText: reported with the concomitant use of propranolol

sentence.text: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS) have been reported to blunt the antihypertensive effect of beta-adrenoreceptor blocking agents.

mmtx.phraseText: the antihypertensive effect of beta-adrenoreceptor blocking agents.

sentence.text: Administration of indomethacin with propranolol may reduce the efficacy of propranolol in reducing blood pressure and heart rate.
Thyroxine may result in a lower than expected T3 concentration when used concomitantly with propranolol.
Propranolol when administered with warfarin increases the concentration of warfarin.
Prothrombin time, therefore, should be monitored.

ellipsisSentence.text: Propranolol when administered with warfarin increases the concentration of warfarin.
Propranolol when administered with warfarin increases the concentration of warfarin.

sentence.text: On a body surface area basis, this dose in the mouse and rat is, respectively, about equal to and about twice the maximum recommended human oral daily dose (MRHD) of 640 mg propranolol HCl.
